is there some sort of story behind "At the Corner Store"? Maybe you simply went to the store and thought about that melody, or it was just like "Fly Around" which you said was just a melody between some chords?

on a song generation session, i just started playing a Bb bass note at a certain tempo, and then the melodic/chord riff popped into mind. sort of a dummy lyric came with it, that said "at the corner store, getting things you need for the brand new world". i made a specific note to myself NOT to use that lyric, because i was tired of all the store/retail references in my work. and i also have some more upcoming store-related material (which i like) that i'd rather not cannibalize. So the first thing on the writing session was to try to find anything alse besides the store, to put on that riff. but nothing else fit as well as the corner store. i relented and made it about the store.

I really appreciate this question section because it's nice to see people asking the same questions I have and knowing that people are the same as me. thanks. Anyway, I am writing because I realized there is something wrong with me. I was talking to a friend about when we used to be super busy. I asked her how she was not miserable when she was overloaded not only with school and extracurriculars, but also heavy work shifts. She said "I wasn't miserable. I was happy." Which made me realize how much I am not like that. I was miserable with half the schedule she had, and I continue to dread any amount of work that comes my way no matter how minuscule or easy. Except for I think I have a slightly smaller aversion when it comes to practicing music, though perhaps I would start to hate it if I pursued it as a serious education/career path. So I'm trying to make instrumental music with new techniques - instead of programming all of it I combine programming with physical equipment (drum machine& synthesizer), having a more loose collective of styles rather than being more stylistically focused, making generally longer songs, practicing buildups, possibly adding in vocals/lyrics, etc.

But it's been really frustrating because I've gotten so good at the much more creatively limited methods I used before, and it feels like I'm back to square one to a degree. 

I tried going back to old methods and it's going great. I'm getting way more music done than I have been in months. But it feels *too* easy, if that makes sense. Like I could come up with a lot more creative and imaginative stuff if I wasn't just hypnotically pumping out the same stuff I'd always done.

I guess my question is, is it possible for creative projects to be *too* easy to make? How do I know when  I've hit that creative hotspot to make truly great art?

what chords did you play in "i'm scared" at the parts where it goes "i'm scared of my own face", "yes i do is that true?", "it's a bad and good tune& i would sing it to you", and "the things that i love to be scared of", respectively?

"scared of my own face", i assume, is Csus2/E Dsus4/F#
"yes i do is that true" would be some kind of Dmin9(11), then some kind of Gmin11. You can probably pretty closely approximate these by using Cadd4/D, and Bbsus2/G
"it's a bad and good tune and i would sing it to you".... "bad and" is generally Dmin11 and Dmin7. "Good tune" is roughly Cmaj and Bbmaj triads, and the bass is in the middle of a climb which would put it on F and G at that time, making the chords you hear something like C/F and Gmin7. "And I" would be something like Gmin11, but because the bass is midway through a climb, in reality what you hear is probably something like Bbsus2/A. "would sing" would just be Bbsus2, and "it" the melody goes to A note, so i'd say this would sound like F/Bb, except this syllable is such a ghost that there's really not much of anything there. and "to you" comes out as F/C, C
"Things that i" should be some kind of F#min7. "Love" should be something like Dmin/F.
"be scared of" is some kind of Bmin9(11), which can be more specifically described as Aadd4 over B. The bass tumbles into this, so the bass doesn't reach the bottom until around "of"

what is a minor chord?

if you have notes C, Eb, and G together, and especially if there is also a C note in a fairly low range, that is probably considered a C minor chord. The same thing could be said about G minor, with notes G, Bb, and D, with G in the bass. and so on, with any groups of notes in this same relative orientation to each other
and what is a major chord?

if you have notes C, E, and G together, and especially if there is also a C note in a fairly low range, that is probably considered a C major chord. The same thing could be said about G major, with notes G, B, and D, with G in the bass. and so on, with any groups of notes in this same relative orientation to each other
how do chord names work?
there is an attempt to describe a chord, using small combinations of letters and numbers
what's sus?

for example, if you have a C major chord (with notes C, E, and G) and you swap out the E note for F instead (C, F, G), this new chord would often be considered Csus4. If you swap the note for D instead (C, D, G), it might be considered Csus2. If there is no number in the chord symbol and it just says Csus, it would almost definitely be assumed to be Csus4. but if you're a person who uses both sus2 and sus4 frequently, it's probably good to specify the number

what is your process for writing a full-fledged song after finishing song selection?

go in order. Sometimes the first item i have does not belong at the beginning, so in that case i have to solve like a weird puzzle to find the beginning. Once i have that, it goes in order. from that point, i try to refresh my mind as good as i can, and then do a real-time play-through of the material, and then when it gets to the end, i listen carefully for lightning to strike and come up with the next section. If i don't get anything, then i refresh again and do a another run through. If i do it several times and still don't get the next part, then i'm considered "stuck". in that case, i might do some discussion about what is going on-- and i try to categorically hone in on what might be the right answer. usually what i really need when i'm stuck is a stronger refresh. the best way to do that is to take some time away from it, but if i don't have time for that, sometimes running cold water on my face can work surprisingly well. and then do the run through, and it feels fresh again, and i'd be more likely to hear the next part

The "when, where, were, we're" segment of "if the world doesn't end" is one of my favorite moments you've ever written, both lyrically and musically. It sounds great and gives me the feeling of an epiphany when I hear it. How did that come about? And why "when"? Why not "why" or "what"? Something about the sound of "when"?

if i could try to psychoanalyze what might have happened here, i'd say the line starts "here you are, there we were", so i think after saying 2 W words in a row, i think that sets a train in motion where you wanna keep going. And the previous 2 phrases started with "here" and "there", ... so you wanna say "where", and also "when", and of course "where" is naturally followed by "were", and then "were" easily transforms to "we're", and of course everyone loves a fun apostrophe game, and then now you're set up for an echo of the same line in the previous verse in that place (around again), and also fits with the point of the song (the world not ending). This is just my analysis of the line after the fact. when writing it, i'm pretty sure everything from "when" to the end of the line came immediately. Oh right, you were asking why it's not "why" or "what" instead of "when"... and the best thing i can suggest is, try imagining it with those other 2 choices... in my opinion i think that sounds much worse

How did you get inspiration for "At the corner store"?

just started pedaling a Bb bass note at a certain tempo, and then the melody/chord riff came, like (ref: write20211018054752.mp3"target="_blank">this (from october 18, 2021). then the next time i looked at it, i think i had sort of a dummy lyric which seemed to fit, like (ref: write20211020104256.mp3"target="_blank)this (from october 20, 2021). and at that time i also acknowledged that "when i close my eyes" also seems might be another option for a later verse somewhere. I was quite certain that i did NOT want the "corner store" to be the primary lyric. i suspected that a second verse might say "at the corner store, getting things you need for the brand new world" or something. Then for the production cycle due on 4/19/22, this song was selected, purely based on the musical riff, and again with the caveat that the "corner store) will NOT be the primary lyric, nor the title. The first several hours of the songwriting session were promptly spent trying vehemently to come up with something 'better' than the corner store line. vague themes of morning/awakening were floating around, some sort of idea of some kind of congregation or club, feelings of renewal, ..... these were the vibes i was going for, but i never came up with anything that fit. At times like these, after a certain amount of toiling, you have to just accept destiny and go with what you've got

If songs are written when you're not thinking, how can I create a system wherein I can not think about 1 specific song at a time long enough for it to eventually be fully written? It seems like I would have to use a fair bit of thought just to keep a song of my choice on the chopping block

the best way i know is to "reset" your mind and then do a run-through of what you have so far, in real time. The fresher you are, the more likely you will clearly see the song for what it is, and get something. The best way to achieve this sort of 'reset' of 'freshness', unfortunately, is to go for a long period of time without hearing the song, and then hear a real-time run through for the first time. Then as soon as you hit the end of that run through, that's when the next part is most likely to hit you. And if it doesn't, ......... well, the best thing to do is reset again and try again. However, the problem is that the best resets take way too much time to do. So if you actually want to get it done, you need a force-reset, and what i typically do is walk over and touch the door handle and come back (then start the run-through). That works a little bit, but not always. What i've discovered recently might be much more effective is to go to the shower and put your face under the cold water. This seems to work shockingly well, and for the past 2 weeks i've been using it repeatedly on everything from writing to music arrangement to video production. it might be the most effective instant-reset method i've ever found. I keep expecting it to wear out but it seems to keep working

https://billwurtz.com/ltr-hello-young-lovers.mp3 hello do you know how i can replicate the wah wah echoey keyboard thing thats doing the chords here. like is there a specific type of effect/midi instrument that can do this

what you wanna do is assign the 'filter cutoff' to one of the wheels. i've assigned it to the mod wheel (which is the wheel next to the pitch bend wheel. the non-springloaded wheel), but you can assign it to any knob you want. then move the knob while you play. moving it yourself is the only way to really get the right effect, otherwise it won't know when to wa. Also you're gonna want to make sure you have a sound that has infinite sustain while you're holding it. (does not decay) (set the 'decay' to zero). that way you can hold it and wawa it forever and it won't go away. also there's no echo on the chords. the delay is on the lead
